posts.name:
Simleen Kaur Arora
Simleen Kaur Arora
posts.content:
𝐇𝐨𝐰 𝐭𝐨 𝐇𝐞𝐥𝐩 𝐚 𝐅𝐫𝐢𝐞𝐧𝐝 𝐨𝐫 𝐅𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐥𝐲 𝐌𝐞𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫 𝐖𝐡𝐨 𝐒𝐞𝐞𝐦𝐬 𝐃𝐞𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐞𝐝

If someone in your known is depressed, here are 3 things you can do:

𝐍𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐫 𝐬𝐚𝐲 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐠𝐬 𝐥𝐢𝐤𝐞 “Just chill,” “Don’t worry,” or “You’re overthinking.” These phrases can make them feel like their emotions are being ignored.

𝐒𝐢𝐭 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐥𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐧 to what they have to say without passing any judgment. Understand and validate their feelings with responses like, “I can see how tough this must be for you.”

𝐌𝐚𝐤𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦 𝐟𝐞𝐞𝐥 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦 and ready to help whenever they need. This assurance can be incredibly helpful in their healing process.

Remember, emotional support helps in their healing.
posts.commentAdded: Such valuable insights! Listening and validating feelings can make a world of difference for someone struggling. Lets promote compassion!

Hard facts, Mark Selinger!

Author (Dunn): “Most investors suck, including some at brand-name VC firms. They are learning on the job, they’ve never built anything, and yet they think they’re awesome.”

All money is not the same. Entrepreneurs need to ignore the traditional alphabet soup of capital raises (Seres A, B, C, D) and maximize bootstrapping, non-dilutive grants, competitions, and consider strategic investments - whether equity, licensing, market eights, etc. Most VCs don’t bring much beyond the money - which isn’t even coming from their own pockets.

posts.content:
AI makes me use my brain more... and less. I solve harder problems faster than I ever thought I could which is great. It also makes me lazy, where some code challenges and problems I depend more and more on LLMs to do things I can actually do faster sometimes 'the old way'.

"Really OpenAI?! You're going to make ME fix THIS bug MYSELF... back to the stone age we go... you really let me down... idiot". I try to hold myself accountable on trying to not use them for things I know my brain should be able to do faster.

comments.commentText: In fairness... your brain is a bit of an outlier! But point very well taken.
It really reframes what "hard" is. Which is interesting. It feels like it will take a bit to adjust to what's possible when dynamic programming becomes for loop easy.

posts.commentAdded: Great insight! Balancing tech reliance and skill growth is key. Let’s embrace challenges while leveraging AI as a tool, not a crutch! 💡

posts.name:
Amir Tabch
Amir Tabch
posts.content:
Squeeze them: People are not Oranges

It’s Monday morning. You’re scrolling LinkedIn over your second cup of coffee, & there it is—a post from a self-proclaimed “Visionary” CEO preaching, “Pay people as little as possible, the minimum, & ask of them the maximum effort. Squeeze them for every drop.” You nearly choke on your coffee. Who writes this? The evil twin of Scrooge McDuck?

Let’s start with the obvious: People are not oranges, & leadership or building a business isn’t about making fresh juice. Yet some so-called leaders—if you can even call them that—seem to think their employees are nothing more than tools to be used, abused, & discarded. What they fail to realize is that this "squeeze them for every drop" approach is not only unethical but also hilariously ineffective.

Research shows that companies prioritizing fair compensation outperform their competitors, achieve higher profitability, greater innovation, & unparalleled employee loyalty. Why? Because happy employees don’t just work harder; they work smarter. They innovate, collaborate, & stick around, reducing costly turnover.

The “minimum pay, maximum effort” philosophy might have worked in feudal times (& even then, the peasants revolted), but in today’s knowledge economy, it’s a death sentence for organizations. Treat employees like replaceable cogs in a machine, & you might enjoy short-term gains, but the long-term consequences are catastrophic. Burnout, high turnover, & a reputation as the workplace equivalent of a black hole—that’s your legacy.

If you need further proof, just look at companies that are thriving because they do the opposite. Take Costco, for example. They pay their employees well above industry standards, & their staff turnover is one of the lowest in retail.

Here’s the irony: Leaders who embrace the "squeeze them" mindset often end up getting squeezed themselves. High turnover means higher recruiting costs, lost productivity, &, let’s face it, some awkward Glassdoor reviews. Imagine future talent Googling your company & finding, "Great place to work if you’re into soul-crushing misery."

But let’s not just laugh at the absurdity—let’s learn from it. Leadership is about investing in people, not exploiting them. Here’s how you avoid being that boss:

• Pay fairly. Period. People aren’t motivated by ramen noodle budgets. Competitive pay shows respect & appreciation for their contributions.

To those who cling to the "minimum pay, maximum effort" mantra: Take a long, hard look in the mirror. If your reflection looks like a 14th-century feudal lord, it’s time to upgrade your leadership philosophy. Because here’s the truth: Employees aren’t the problem. Leaders who think like this are.

In the wise words of Richard Branson, “Train people well enough so they can leave, treat them well enough so they don’t want to.” It’s not rocket science. It’s human decency. & as it turns out, decency is pretty darn profitable.

comments.commentText: Does anyone else find that learning from contrasting examples can be really effective?
Absolutely agree. Investing in employees fosters loyalty and innovation. A thriving workplace culture not only boosts morale but ultimately drives long-term success and profitability.

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Investing in employees leads to a thriving culture. Let’s prioritize respect and fairness for sustainable success.

posts.name:
Leslie Venetz
Leslie Venetz
posts.content:
The # 1 change you need to make to your outbound emails in 2025 if you expect your prospects to reply. 



Make your emails shorter.

Make your LinkedIn messages EVEN shorter.


️ 3 reasons why this is a MUST if you expect to
to your prospect's attention:


1. Optimize for mobile

Depending on who you ask, the optimal length of a cold outbound sales email is 16-130 words.

Regardless of the source, the consensus is shorter emails get better results.

One reason is that shorter emails can be read on a mobile device without having to scroll.

If your prospect can read your CTA without having to scroll you are significantly more likely to get a reply.


2. Reduce mental load

Shorter emails, especially those that utilize spacing between sentences get higher reply rates.

Short, simple sentences are easier for prospects to scan and quickly absorb.

By writing short, simple emails with ample spacing, you're making it easier for your prospect to engage with your email.


3. Make a point that matters TO THEM

Shorter emails force you to get to the point!

Write straightforward emails that focus on what matters to your prospect (HINT: eliminate as much I, We, Our language as you can) and you'll see an increase in your reply rates within the week.


 What word or character count do you aim for when writing sales emails?
posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Shortening emails is key to capturing attention in todays fast-paced world. Cant wait to see the impact on response rates!

posts.name:
Véronique Barrot
Véronique Barrot
posts.content:
Hiring kind people with a positive attitude is better than 

hiring negative people with experience. 

Skills might open the door...

But attitude is what 𝘱𝘶𝘴𝘩𝘦𝘴 you up the ladder.

Here are 10 ways your positive attitude can skyrocket your career:

1. Stronger Teamwork:
↳ Positivity brings people together, making collaboration feel effortless.

2. Boosted Productivity:
↳ A positive mindset = more energy, more focus, more results.

3. Smarter Problem-Solving:
↳ When you face challenges with optimism, they become opportunities.

4. Clearer Communication:
↳ Positive energy creates clearer, more impactful conversations.

5. Lower Stress:
↳ A happy environment is the best stress-buster. It’s contagious.

6. Better Retention:
↳ Happy employees stay longer. It's that simple.

7. Attracting the Best Talent:
↳ Good vibes attract great people. A positive team draws in top talent.

8. Happier Customers:
↳ Happy employees = happy customers. It’s a powerful cycle.

9. Innovation in Motion:
↳ Positivity fuels the courage to think outside the box.

10. Building Leaders:
↳ Positive environments create leaders, not followers.

Skills? Yes, they matter.

But attitude is the game-changer.

Which one are you bringing to the table today?

Skills or attitude?
Let me know in the comments.⬇️

Tag a colleague who embodies positivity in the workplace!

Repost to help others in your network have a positive attitude. ️
And followfor more personal and professional growth insights.

Ready to shift your mindset and boost your life, leadership, and career?
My newsletter has you covered:
(+ you'll get 100+ high-value resources.)

Let's foster positive change in people and organisations globally.

comments.commentText: Positivity is the engine that drives teamwork, creativity, and success. A strong attitude can transform even the toughest days into opportunities for greatness!
comments.userName: Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor

comments.commentText: Couldn’t have put it better! Positivity is the catalyst for turning challenges into stepping stones. Thanks, Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! A positive attitude not only elevates individual performance but also transforms team dynamics. Lets spread those good vibes! 🌟

posts.name:
Neil Sarkar
Neil Sarkar
posts.content:
Still guessing your way to closed deals? Here’s the data-driven reality check you didn’t know you needed

Let’s face it—“working smarter, not harder” is impossible if you don’t know what smart looks like. Data is the difference between being a deal-closing machine and the sales equivalent of flipping coins. But here’s the kicker: most sales teams are using data all wrong!

Let me break it down:

1. Your data might be lying to you
Bad data is worse than no data. If your CRM is bloated with outdated, incomplete, or just plain wrong info, you’re not data-driven—you’re data-delusional.
Fix it: Regularly audit your data. Clean it, enrich it, and—if needed—burn the useless bits. Your team’s intuition can’t save a bad foundation.

2. Focus on Actionable Insights, Not Vanity Metrics
Sure, it feels good to say, “We had 5,000 new leads last month!” But if only 2 converted, who cares? Stop tracking metrics that make you look busy and start digging into metrics that matter:
️ Lead response time
️ Conversion rates by stage
️ Deal velocity
Pro Tip: If your sales meetings sound like a highlight reel of meaningless stats, you’re focusing on the wrong KPIs.

3. Predictive Analytics = Your Secret Weapon
Forget reactive reporting; it’s like reading yesterday’s weather forecast. Predictive analytics tells you what’s coming next:
️ Which leads are likely to convert
️ How long a deal will take
️ Which team member should handle a specific account
It’s like giving your sales team superpowers. They’re not just working harder—they’re working smarter, faster, and with laser focus.

4.The Human Touch Still Wins (But Data Makes It Better)
Here’s where it gets tricky: data is the fuel, not the driver. It can tell you what your customer cares about, but it can’t deliver an empathetic pitch. Use data to tee up personalized, meaningful conversations—then let your human touch close the deal.
Case in point: One of our reps noticed a lead repeatedly visiting our pricing page. Instead of the usual script, they led with, “Let’s talk about how we can make our pricing work for you.” Boom, instant connection.

TAKEAWAY
Being data-driven isn’t about staring at dashboards until your eyes bleed—it’s about using data to make smarter, faster decisions that lead to real results.
Bad data? Fix it. Vanity metrics? Skip ‘em. Predictive analytics? Embrace it. And for goodness’ sake, don’t forget the human touch.

Your move: Stop guessing, start learning, and let data put you in the driver’s seat. Who’s ready to level up?
posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Data is indeed key to smarter selling. Let’s leverage it effectively and transform our sales strategies! 🚀
